description: Part of the power of Python is the array of tools that come built into the language, known as the Python Standard Library. In this series, we take a look at the Standard Library, import from the Standard Library, as well as take a view of some of the more common modules, or parts, of the Standard Library. If you want to dive a little deeper, then we will see you there.

If you want to dive a little deeper, then we will see you there.
name: Use the Standard Library
subtitle: The Power of Python

episodes.description: Part of the power of Python is the array of tools that come built into the language, known as the Python Standard Library. In this series, we take a look at the Standard Library, import from the Standard Library, as well as take a view of some of the more common modules, or parts, of the Standard Library. If you want to dive a little deeper, then we will see you there.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.052
[SOUND] Hello, and thank you for

2
00:00:05.052 --> 00:00:08.923
watching DevProTV.

3
00:00:08.923 --> 00:00:13.400
Today we're gonna be talking about use
the standard library with Justin Denison.

4
00:00:13.400 --> 00:00:16.440
Now Justin, can you tell us
about what this course has to

5
00:00:16.440 --> 00:00:18.130
offer the people out there?
>> So

6
00:00:18.130 --> 00:00:22.140
Python's called a batteries included
language, and, well, up until this point

7
00:00:22.140 --> 00:00:26.360
we've kind of been dabbling just in the
things that are just readily available.

8
00:00:26.360 --> 00:00:30.440
However, that's not all the power that's
available in Python, we have this

9
00:00:30.440 --> 00:00:35.420
expansive set of other functionalities
that are called the standard libraries, so

10
00:00:35.420 --> 00:00:37.230
we are gonna be exploring
that a little bit.

11
00:00:37.230 --> 00:00:39.340
>> Okay, so who should watch this show?

12
00:00:39.340 --> 00:00:40.710
>> This is a show for

13
00:00:40.710 --> 00:00:42.290
someone who's just getting
started programming,

14
00:00:42.290 --> 00:00:46.200
predictably programming in Python because
that's what we're gonna be talking about.

15
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:49.080
Well, your like, I feel comfortable,
right, with creating lists and

16
00:00:49.080 --> 00:00:52.660
tuples and now I want to do a little more.

17
00:00:52.660 --> 00:00:57.010
I'm trying to figure out well,
I need to manage some dates, right?

18
00:00:57.010 --> 00:00:59.360
I need to figure out
how to work with times.

19
00:00:59.360 --> 00:01:03.180
It's meant to help level up
your Python programming skills.

20
00:01:03.180 --> 00:01:05.910
>> Is this a certification-based course?

21
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:08.230
>> It is not certification-based.

22
00:01:08.230 --> 00:01:13.123
As I've already said, it is meant to
help you progress in your understanding

23
00:01:13.123 --> 00:01:16.006
of Python and programming in general.
>> Could you

24
00:01:16.006 --> 00:01:18.987
tell us a little bit more about what
topics will be covered in user standard

25
00:01:18.987 --> 00:01:21.640
library?
>> So I'm gonna take a look at some of

26
00:01:21.640 --> 00:01:27.210
the topics that I used most when I
first started programming in Python.

27
00:01:27.210 --> 00:01:30.040
That's the datetime module
where we can manage dates,

28
00:01:30.040 --> 00:01:33.170
times, and well, together, datetimes.

29
00:01:33.170 --> 00:01:34.210
I know it's kind of an odd thing.

30
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:38.595
We also explore what the concept
of a date or a time is.

31
00:01:38.595 --> 00:01:43.370
We also see how to use OS
specific functionalities,

32
00:01:43.370 --> 00:01:46.951
including how to manage file paths, or

33
00:01:46.951 --> 00:01:51.631
folder paths, and
kind of poking around on those.

34
00:01:51.631 --> 00:01:54.537
Look at a little bit of randomness and

35
00:01:54.537 --> 00:02:00.466
manipulating the underlying system
portion for Python, like settings.

36
00:02:00.466 --> 00:02:02.045
How does the interpreter run?

37
00:02:02.045 --> 00:02:03.670
How does the runtime run?

38
00:02:03.670 --> 00:02:06.310
And how to change those.

39
00:02:06.310 --> 00:02:11.330
We also spend a little bit of time,
how do I get access to those?

40
00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:12.390
How do those come in?

41
00:02:12.390 --> 00:02:14.230
Why are they just available?

42
00:02:14.230 --> 00:02:16.820
I can't just use those?

43
00:02:16.820 --> 00:02:17.560
How do I bring those in?

44
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:20.991
So those are a few of the topics
that we're gonna take a look at.

45
00:02:20.991 --> 00:02:24.156
And, well, I will tell you,
it seems not that difficult but

46
00:02:24.156 --> 00:02:28.005
it can get a little deep, so you might
wanna bring your hip waiters as far as

47
00:02:28.005 --> 00:02:32.091
that is concerned.
>> All right, Justin, thank you so much,

48
00:02:32.091 --> 00:02:37.141
and if user standard library is something
that interests you, and you wanna be

49
00:02:37.141 --> 00:02:42.419
the one step closer to being a Python pro,
be sure to check out every single episode

50
00:02:42.419 --> 00:02:47.965
that user standard library has to offer in
our course library, thanks for watching.

51
00:02:47.965 --> 00:02:48.465
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri take a brief tour of the Python standard library documentation as well as discuss the utility of the standard library.
episodes.title: What is the Standard Library

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri take a look at several ways to import modules from the Python standard library. Justin highlights the pros and cons of the different import methods.
episodes.title: Access the Standard Library

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri explore some of the common functionality that is sometimes needed from the os module.
episodes.title: Use the os Module

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri dive into the os.path module for manipulating, creating, and inspecting file paths. Justin explores the functions that provide functionality for each of those areas as well as discusses the headaches that os.path alleviates.
episodes.title: Use the os.path Module

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri dive into the os.path module for manipulating, creating, and inspecting file paths. Justin explores the functions that provide functionality for each of those areas as well as discusses the headaches that os.path alleviates.
episodes.title: Use the os.path Module Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri talk about handling dates and times in Python. Justin discusses the representation of dates and times in many programming languages then dives into the datetime module to demonstrate how that module makes things easier to reason about by creating dates, times, and datetimes.
episodes.title: Use the datetime Module: Getting Started

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri continue their discussion about handling dates, times, and datetimes in Python. Justin explores the use of timedelta objects, the representation of changes in datetimes, in order to create a new datetime object as well as how timedeltas are produced when doing math with dates, times, and datetimes.
episodes.title: Use the datetime Module: Timedeltas and Arithmetic

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri further explore the datetime module by exploring the ability to compare datetime objects.
episodes.title: Use the datetime Module: Comparisons

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri finish up the exploring the datetime module by parsing, converting text, to datetimes. Additionally, Justin demonstrates how to take a datetime, create a formatted string from that object, and basic usage of the timezone objects.
episodes.title: Use the datetime Module: Parsing and Timezones

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri jump into learning some math using Python. Justin demonstrates the use of the math module to bring in some additional math functions that are needed from time to time.
episodes.title: Use the math Module

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri take a look at the sys module in the Python standard library. Justin explores the interpreter settings for Python and demonstrates the settings that are commonly used.
episodes.title: Use the sys Module: Interpreter Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri continue their exploration of the sys module in the Python standard library. Justin demonstrates the runtime environment portion of the sys module such as command line options, status codes, and input/output streams available to Python.
episodes.title: Use the sys Module: Runtime Environment

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri wrap up their look into the sys module by exploring the settings and functionality provided around the modules and imports that are running in Python. Justin highlights some useful aspects of being able to look at imports and the modules that are available to Python.
episodes.title: Use the sys Module: Modules and Imports

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Aubri dive into the random module. Justin demonstrates the generation of random numbers and ranges using module level functions as well as how to manage multiple random states using objects.
episodes.title: Use the random Module
